Welcome to How To Cook That, I'm Ann Reardon andÂ 
this week we are debunking, debunking, debunking!Â Â

You guys have sent me heaps more viral videos toÂ 
debunk ... if you want to send me something justÂ Â

submit the link to me on twitter so that i canÂ 
watch it and check it out. This first one comesÂ Â

from Oliver and heaps more people sent me this oneÂ 
as well but Oliver was first and he is asking doesÂ Â

this work? Basically they take popcorn put it inÂ 
a pan add some chocolate then add oil, stir it upÂ Â

until the popcorn starts popping put the lidÂ 
on and voila! Chocolate-flavored popcorn.Â Â

Well Oliver thinks the chocolate will burn I tendÂ 
to agree but as always let's check it out and seeÂ Â

what happens ... put the corn kernels in the panÂ 
add the chocolate in the middle just like they didÂ Â

and then add the oil. Turn it on to heat upÂ 
and stir it until it just starts to pop andÂ Â

then quickly put the lid on so we don't getÂ 
a mess everywhere wait a few moments and ifÂ Â

you could smell the room right now you would knowÂ 
that that is smoke not steam coming off the pan.Â Â

Oh gosh I'll put some of the nicer lookingÂ 
ones of these in a bowl for Dave to try.Â Â

I'm avoiding the ones that look like thisÂ 
... totally black. There are plenty of thoseÂ Â

let me show you the pan's still got heaps ofÂ 
unpopped popcorn kernels down the bottom thereÂ Â

and the chocolate mixture is burnt and stuck toÂ 
the bottom of the pan. ğŸ™…â€â™‚ï¸ It looks pretty good.

oh that's burnt as ... noÂ 
thank you. Oh that's bad!

We've already debunked a very similar videoÂ 
that used Skittles to do the same thing,Â Â

so why doesn't this work? Well in this instanceÂ 
chocolate will burn at 95 degrees centigrade,Â Â

the sugar in the chocolate or in the skittles orÂ 
whatever you're using will burn at 176 degreesÂ Â

centigrade, and popcorn doesn't pop untilÂ 
the kernel reaches 180 degrees centigrade.Â Â

so you have to have the oil at least 180 and holdÂ 
it there in order to heat up that kernel enough toÂ Â

make it pop in the meantime you've then burntÂ 
the sugar or definitely burnt your chocolate.Â Â

So if you really are craving chocolate popcornÂ 
here's what you can do you need to pop the cornÂ Â

first separately with no chocolate on it and thenÂ 
melt some chocolate and I'm just adding some extraÂ Â

fat into that to thin it down I'm using cocoaÂ 
butter and then just microwave that to melt it.Â Â

Add a couple of handfuls of your popcorn in atÂ 
a time into the chocolate now if you're usingÂ Â

real chocolate like I am it's going to needÂ 
tempering or it's just going to stay stickyÂ Â

it's not going to set firm so once it's startingÂ 
to cool I'm just adding some more freeze-driedÂ Â

cocoa butter in here to help it to set. If you'reÂ 
using compound chocolate you totally don't haveÂ Â

to worry about that you can skip that step andÂ 
then just spread it out and leave it to set.

Hmmmm. So popcorny so chocolaty,Â 
delicious! I'll have another ğŸ’

Katie sent in this next video and she says sheÂ 
thinks it's 100% fake but the comments seem toÂ Â

disagree with other people saying it's true, soÂ 
let's check it out. The guy gets some sticky tapeÂ Â

puts it on his head rips it off and then puts thatÂ 
under a microscope and shows us all the littleÂ Â

creatures that you can see crawling around on hisÂ 
face. Well Katie it is true we do have microscopicÂ Â

little creatures crawling around on our faceÂ 
that we can't even see because they're so small.Â Â

Usually if you wanted to see them you wouldÂ 
use a microscopic slide or scientists wouldÂ Â

and some super glue and put it on and rip itÂ 
off so you rip out some hair follicles becauseÂ Â

face mites live in the hair follicle theyÂ 
eat the sebum around your hair, gross hey!Â Â

But if you just put sticky tape on and ripÂ 
it off like that you're not going to getÂ Â

face mites on there if you put the sticky tapÂ 
on you can get them if you then made it reallyÂ Â

dark and you stayed really still for a long timeÂ 
because they can come out when you're asleep inÂ Â

the dark but he didn't do that obviously. There isÂ 
a great channel called Microbe Hunter and he has aÂ Â

video on how you can actually get some face marksÂ 
so that you can look at them under the microscopeÂ Â

and i'll put a link to his video below because heÂ 
explains it all in detail for you. But that is notÂ Â

what we're seeing on the tiktok video they'reÂ 
not face mites they're completely different,Â Â

so what has he shown us is on his face? Well i'mÂ 
no microbiologist but i would say that this oneÂ Â

here is a copepod which is found in all sorts ofÂ 
water freshwater, saltwater all over the placeÂ Â

and then this other one here on the left looks aÂ 
bit like hydra and the one in the middle looks toÂ Â

me like a daphnia or a water flea which lives inÂ 
swamps lakes or ponds. So we can deduct either heÂ Â

has just come fresh out from swimming in a pond inÂ 
his backyard and is still so wet that he could getÂ Â

a sample that had water in it and they can stillÂ 
swim around or he's totally faked it and yes ifÂ Â

you notice there was one there that i didn't tellÂ 
you what it was because i want you super-smartÂ Â

people to do your own research and figure out whatÂ 
microbe that was that i didn't tell you about.Â Â

Okay moving on this next one has been a long timeÂ 
in the making i was sent this video six months agoÂ Â

which shows that you should store onions in aÂ 
stocking and tie a knot and I was sent it by soÂ Â

many people and it says that they will last forÂ 
up to six months hence why i started filming thisÂ Â

six months ago! So i took some onions and i putÂ 
them into a stocking separating each one with aÂ Â

knot and then putting another one in but so thatÂ 
we had a control i also took some onions that iÂ Â

bought on the same day from the same store and putÂ 
them into a lined basket and i just stored thatÂ Â

in the cupboard. It's finally been six months soÂ 
let's check out what has happened to these onions.Â Â

Let's take them out of the stocking cut themÂ 
all out ... the first one here looks a littleÂ Â

mouldy but it's still firm the other two lookÂ 
pretty good. Now the advantage of keeping themÂ Â

separate like this is if one does get moldy itÂ 
doesn't spread to the other ones. Now for theÂ Â

ones in the basket well they look very similar toÂ 
me they all look pretty good they're still firm,Â Â

now let's cut them open the top row are the onesÂ 
from the stocking and this one that i'm cuttingÂ Â

now was from the basket and they both look fineÂ 
to me. So the moral of the story is onions canÂ Â

last for a really long time they don't have toÂ 
be stored in a stocking. Storing them separatelyÂ Â

does help if one goes off doesn't affect allÂ 
of the rest but you can just spread them outÂ Â

in a basket you don't need to get a stocking itÂ 
just makes it hard to grab an onion when you wantÂ Â

to cook with it. Now before i move on big thankÂ 
you to everybody who came to the book signing inÂ Â

Melbourne that was so lovely to meet you all weÂ 
have more book signings coming up in Sydney andÂ Â

Perth please do check the link below regularlyÂ 
for updates to those dates because things keepÂ Â

shifting around with red zones and restrictionsÂ 
and all of that stuff we have to make sure weÂ Â

stick to what we are allowed to do, so check thatÂ 
link below to find out when they are. And when IÂ Â

was looking for the videos for today the onesÂ 
you'd submitted on Twitter I also saw so manyÂ Â

photos people had shared when they excitedly gotÂ 
their cookbook just as excited as I was when I gotÂ Â

mine finally and so what I thought I'd do is runÂ 
another competition so we have 10 Wiltshire prizeÂ Â

packs to give away and they have heaps of bakingÂ 
gear that will be great when you're making thingsÂ Â

in the book and I'm going to give away prizesÂ 
for the best photos which have the book in itÂ Â

somewhere. So it doesn't have to just be a zoomÂ 
in of the cover because then they're all goingÂ Â

to look exactly the same so come up with someÂ 
creative ideas for a photo, share that socialÂ Â

media and #crazysweetcreations the name of theÂ 
book so that i can find it. I'm going to giveÂ Â

away two of these prize packs to photos that areÂ 
on Instagram, two to photos that are on TikTok orÂ Â

videos and two that are on Facebook and twoÂ 
that are on YouTube (also 2 on Twitter). SoÂ Â

just hashtag that crazy sweet creations. OkayÂ 
moving on to the next one summer sent me thisÂ Â

video from five-minute crafts that shows youÂ 
how you can tell if your food is organic or notÂ Â

organic. Now i'm sure you would know organicÂ 
means it's been grown without any additionalÂ Â

chemicals and pesticides and all of those thingsÂ 
so let's see what they say in this first oneÂ Â

they have some honey and they put it in a bowl addÂ 
some water on top and swirl it around and then theÂ Â

honey gets this sort of honeycomb type pattern onÂ 
it and they're saying if it gets the pattern it isÂ Â

organic, if it doesn't get the pattern it is notÂ 
organic. So let's test it out and see what happensÂ Â

we have lots of great honeys here inÂ 
Australia so just put some honey on a plateÂ Â

add some water and swirl it around in a circularÂ 
motion and look a honeycomb pattern so does thatÂ Â

mean that my honey is organic? Now this test hasÂ 
been around for a long time there were old videosÂ Â

that said that this was honey showing its "geneticÂ 
memory" of how it was stored in the honeycomb andÂ Â

that's why it had this pattern when you swirlÂ 
water on it and you could tell if that was pureÂ Â

honey or if it was impure honey it wouldn't formÂ 
the pattern. Well, it's actually just a load ofÂ Â

rubbish! The pattern that's forming is because ofÂ 
the water swirling over it you've got the viscousÂ Â

honey which can be moved slowly by the water andÂ 
the water that's moving quickly over it and it'sÂ Â

changing the position of the honey in the bowl. IÂ 
can prove that to you by just changing how i swirlÂ Â

the water, if i swirl the water from side to sideÂ 
this would work even better in a square containerÂ Â

but it's going to work in a round one then you canÂ 
see the pattern is now different ... it looks moreÂ Â

like a wave pattern and that's because it is theÂ 
water that is making the pattern on the honey. IÂ Â

can show you again with just a different liquidÂ 
that's not honey if i use golden syrup which isÂ Â

definitely not honey it's just man-made usingÂ 
sugar and if i swirl that round and round andÂ Â

round then we end up with the same honeycombÂ 
pattern, it is not a test of pure honey, it'sÂ Â

not a test of if honey is organic or not. It'sÂ 
just, it's not a test it just shows you patternsÂ Â

you can make using water and a viscous liquid.Â 
So just totally forget that one. There is anÂ Â

issue with honey though there was a thing calledÂ 
Honeygate about four or five years ago where theyÂ Â

tested samples of all these differentÂ 
honeys and found that they had actually beenÂ Â

watered down using other sugar syrups becauseÂ 
it's a lot cheaper to produce. As you would knowÂ Â

bees go to flowers they go to thousands of flowersÂ 
to get nectar just tiny little bits of nectar fromÂ Â

each flower they bring it back to the hive andÂ 
then they start to digest that in their honeyÂ Â

stomach and then they spit that partially digestedÂ 
nectar out and give it to another bee who thenÂ Â

adds more enzymes in their stomach and it keepsÂ 
getting passed from bee to bee until eventuallyÂ Â

it goes into one of those little honeycomb cells.Â 
They then use heat and airflow by fanning theirÂ Â

wings to evaporate that off and just thicken itÂ 
up and then they just cover it with wax on the topÂ Â

and the enzymes process that nectar andÂ 
we get honey. Now that is quite a bigÂ Â

extensive process if you can just use sugar syrupÂ 
instead that's going to be heaps cheaper. IfÂ Â

you're buying pure honey you want pure honey youÂ 
don't just want to have corn syrup or rice syrupÂ Â

mixed into it so how can we test to see if you'veÂ 
got pure honey? Well there's a new test that'sÂ Â

been developed for honey over the last few yearsÂ 
because of all of the cheating that was going onÂ Â

and it uses nuclear magnetic resonance orÂ 
NMR and it doesn't just show if there'sÂ Â

other syrups present it can also show where theÂ 
honey originated from because some honeys areÂ Â

more highly prized than others like your ManukaÂ 
honey. All of that before was a bit of a mysteryÂ Â

you had to trust what the people said on theÂ 
label but now with this test they can actuallyÂ Â

check that it is originating from where it said itÂ 
was originating from. So to find out if the honeyÂ Â

that you're getting at the shops is pure you'dÂ 
need to check if in your country they use this NMRÂ Â

test to double check any imported honey and honeyÂ 
made within the country to make sure it says whatÂ Â

it is if it's not then it's a little hard for youÂ 
to tell you definitely cannot swirl it in waterÂ Â

it's not going to help you. Okay moving on to theÂ 
next one in the same video they say we can test ifÂ Â

butter is organic or not organic by putting it inÂ 
some warm water and stirring it and then it saysÂ Â

that non-organic butter dissolves slowly andÂ 
leaves a greasy surface on the water. Well iÂ Â

think if you just pause the video and think aboutÂ 
that you would know that fat doesn't dissolve inÂ Â

water fat floats to the top that's what it doesÂ 
and butter is predominantly fat, you've got someÂ Â

proteins from the milk and the cream inÂ 
there and that's what's going to make theÂ Â

water cloudy down the bottom but the fat shouldÂ 
float to the top that's what it's supposed to do.Â Â

I can show you i have three different buttersÂ 
here two of them are organic one of them is notÂ Â

and if I stir them all then you can see that theÂ 
fat indeed floats to the top and they all lookÂ Â

identical. So where did the yellow fat go in theirÂ 
video it was there at the beginning granted thereÂ Â

wasn't as much because they put heaps of butterÂ 
in the one and only a little bit in the other oneÂ Â

but if i show you frame by frame you see if youÂ 
can tell where the video has been cut ... there'sÂ Â

not really any reason to cut it there unless youÂ 
are swapping it out so you're either swappingÂ Â

glasses or you're just taking some of the fat outÂ 
by absorbing it on a paper towel who knows whatÂ Â

they did and the weird thing about this is becauseÂ 
they're using tests that people can repeat at homeÂ Â

like the honey one but giving people the wrongÂ 
conclusions, people do the honey and go oh wowÂ Â

this must be true but really you've justÂ 
been given completely wrong informationÂ Â

for the experiment that you're conducting. OkayÂ 
moving on rice is next on their list we can tellÂ Â

if it's organic according to them by puttingÂ 
it in oil and if it's organic it will puff upÂ Â

and float to the top and if it's not organic itÂ 
will sink to the bottom and if you leave it longÂ Â

enough it will start to go brown like their'sÂ 
has because they have overcooked it there.Â Â

So we'll add in the rice that is not organic firstÂ 
and you can see contrary to their video it isÂ Â

popping and puffing up and coming to the top thisÂ 
will actually happen whether the rice is organicÂ Â

or not, brown rice, white rice they'll all doÂ 
it. And now if i put some in that is organic riceÂ Â

it's not popping it's just sinking to the bottomÂ 
so why is that is there test the wrong way around?Â Â

No i just changed another factor in thatÂ 
experiment which was the temperature ... you haveÂ Â

to get the oil up to 180 preferably a bit hotterÂ 
degrees centigrade in order for that rice toÂ Â

pop. If you have it too low which is what i didÂ 
with the organic rice it's just going to sinkÂ Â

to the bottom and sit there unless you increaseÂ 
the temperature of that oil it's not going to popÂ Â

like that so this is the organic rice and it'sÂ 
popped perfectly, this is the non-organic riceÂ Â

and it's popped perfectly and this is actuallyÂ 
cooked rice that has been dried in the ovenÂ Â

that goes even more a bit like a Rice Bubble butÂ 
greasy or a prawn cracker more probably but don'tÂ Â

just do straight boiled rice if it's got any waterÂ 
in it it's going to just make the oil splatterÂ Â

everywhere you'll probably get oil burns on youÂ 
so don't do that if you boil your rice and cook itÂ Â

you then have to spread it out on a tray and dryÂ 
out in a dehydrator until it's completely dry thenÂ Â

you can fry it and you'll get that sort of prawnÂ 
cracker consistency. Moving on next they haveÂ Â

parsley this is an interesting one they say we canÂ 
tell if it's organic or not by looking at it i'mÂ Â

not quite sure what they're trying to tell us hereÂ 
are they saying the shorter the stems are cut it'sÂ Â

organic if it says long stems it's not organic?Â 
Really you can't tell using this test it's justÂ Â

not possible it's just a weird test. This videoÂ 
just is not good it's not good information stopÂ Â
